properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Snow will continue to fall over northwestern Alberta tonight, with an additional 10 to 15 cm of accumulations by Saturday morning. The heaviest snow is expected to be south of High Level. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-19T17:49:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T04:39:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2932579671.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense system will produce winds of 90 kilometres per hour or more over these areas today. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-20T01:26:26-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Winds will continue to strengthen along the foothills, with gusts up to 110 km/h possible in some wind prone areas tonight. The winds are then expected to gradually weaken on Saturday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-20T03:14:40-00:00

Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions expected near the Richardson Mountains. A weak weather disturbance moving into central Yukon will create east winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 near the Richardson Mountains this afternoon through Sunday morning. These strong winds will cause poor visibility in blowing snow and wind chill values down to minus 50. Winds are forecast to diminish Sunday afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-20T03:14:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T11:14:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3052182191.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. Wind chill values near minus 45 will moderate this morning. Wind chill values near minus 45 will redevelop tonight into Sunday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-20T02:22:30-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will give blizzard conditions over these areas until Saturday evening. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow causing widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-19T14:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T03:02:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1506153822.2020
Area: Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. A brief but intense snow squall associated with a strong cold front will cross the northern Webequie region tonight. Northwest winds gusting to 70 km/h combined with heavy snow during the passage of the front will likely result in a brief period of very poor visibility. A general snowfall accumulation of 4 to 8 cm is possible. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-19T14:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T03:02:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2434538118.2020
Area: Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chills of -55 or colder are occurring this morning at Baker Lake and Rankin Inlet. Slight moderation away from warning criteria is possible during the day on Saturday before falling back below criteria again tonight. Extreme wind chills may also develop at Chesterfield Inlet overnight tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-20T01:11:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T09:11:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0921795726.2020
Area: Baker Lake, Rankin Region including Whale Cove

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Atmospheric conditions could result in a deterioration in air quality. High levels of pollutants are expected to last until Saturday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canadaâs website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard continues on Saturday. Strong northeasterly winds of 60 gusting to 80 km/h are currently occurring at Coral Harbour as a low pressure system crosses Hudson Bay. The strong winds combined with falling snow is leading to blizzard conditions. Visibilities will remain poor throughout Saturday before improving Saturday evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions lasting until mid day on Saturday. An intense low pressure system over northern Hudson Bay is giving strong easterly winds of 70 gusting to 90 km/h to Kinngait this morning. This is resulting in significantly reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Improvement is expected around mid day on Saturday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-19T20:49:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T04:49:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1227289695.2020
Area: Norman Wells - Tulita Region, Fort Good Hope Region, Deline

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Southerly winds ahead of a cold front continue to generate lake enhanced snow for the region this morning. Reduced visibility in falling snow and snow covered roads could potentially lead to difficult driving conditions, especially along Highway 17. An additional snowfall amount of 2 to 4 cm is expected. Conditions should improve later this morning as the southerly winds weaken. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-19T20:30:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T10:14:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2824241814.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard Saturday. A strong low pressure system is making its way through Hudson Bay toward southern Baffin Island. At Iqaluit, snow will begin Saturday morning along with rapidly intensifying easterly winds. With winds gusting up to 80 km/h, a blizzard will develop in the morning and continue throughout the day. Conditions will improve in the evening as the system moves off into Foxe Basin. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-20T01:04:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T09:04:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0942655094.2020
Area: Iqaluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. A narrow but possibly intense snow squall band, associated with the passage of a cold front, will move across far northeastern Ontario tonight. This linear snow squall band which extends from roughly Peawanuck southwest towards Ogoki at 11:00 PM EST is expected to move eastward throughout the night. It may reach Attawapiskat and Fort Albany near or after midnight, although it will likely be in a weakened state by that time. A snowfall accumulation of 4 to 8 cm is possible with this snow squall. Strong winds with gusts of up to 60 km/h are also possible with the passage of the cold front tonight. These winds are expected to ease Friday overnight. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities may be reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to the reduced visibility. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-19T18:40:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T04:11:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3616652675.2020
Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki, Fort Albany
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. Extreme cold conditions with wind chill values near minus 50 will continue this tonight before moderating by Saturday morning as temperatures rise and cloud cover increases over the region. However, extreme cold conditions are expected to return Saturday afternoon and evening. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Atmospheric conditions could result in a deterioration in air quality. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of freezing drizzle is expected. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: today. Remarks: A mixture of freezing drizzle and flurries will persist through much of the day today. Conditions are expected to improve this afternoon and into this evening as the northeasterly flow weakens. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-19T22:59:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T08:29:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3044317956.2020
Area: Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova

For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the MinistÃ¨re de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in MontrÃ©al, visit the RÃ©seau de surveillance de la qualitÃ© de lâair de la Ville de MontrÃ©alâs website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in QuÃ©bec, visit the MinistÃ¨re de la SantÃ© et des Services sociauxâs website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction rÃ©gionale de santÃ© publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-lâÃle-de-MontrÃ©al at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-12-19T20:59:13-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow over the Icefields Parkway will taper off this morning. However snow at times heavy is expected to redevelop this evening and continue into Sunday, with up to 30 cm of new snow by Sunday afternoon. Locally strong winds with gusts near 70 km/h will also result in blowing snow along some sections of the highway tonight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-20T03:29:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T11:29:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3676788265.2020
Area: Highway 93 - Lake Louise to Saskatchewan River Crossing, Highway 93 - Jasper to Saskatchewan River Crossing

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for tonight. A cold front moving across northern Ontario tonight has brought southerly winds over lake Superior ahead of the front that has enhanced the snowfall amounts. Heavy bursts of snow and significantly reduced visibilities at times can be expected tonight. Travel along Highway 17 during this time may be hazardous. A total snowfall accumulation of 10 to 15 cm is possible by Saturday morning. Areas closer to the lake shore where the temperature is slightly above the freezing mark may accumulate less snow than areas further inland. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-19T18:04:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-19T06:00:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3353643403.2020
Area: White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay

properties.Summary:

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
